questions.prompt: Dynamic programming is most appropriate when a problem has:
questions.explanation: DP exploits overlapping subproblems (reuse) and optimal substructure (optimal solution can be built from optimal subsolutions).

questions.prompt: In matrix-chain multiplication, the DP recurrence typically considers splitting the chain at an index _____.
questions.explanation: The recurrence tries all split points k between i and j and chooses the one minimizing total multiplications.

questions.prompt: The standard matrix-chain multiplication DP runs in O(n^3) time and O(n^2) space.
questions.explanation: The DP fills an n×n table and for each (i, j) considers O(n) split points, yielding O(n^3) time and O(n^2) space.

questions.prompt: Which DP problem is commonly solved using an edit-distance table?
questions.explanation: Edit distance computes the minimum number of edits to transform one string into another using a DP table over prefix lengths.
The code prints the element at index 3 of the array, which is 2.

questions.prompt: In Longest Common Subsequence DP, the table entry dp[i][j] typically represents:
options: LCS length of prefixes X[0..i) and Y[0..j)
Shortest path between i and j
questions.explanation: Standard LCS DP defines dp[i][j] as the LCS length of the first i characters of X and the first j characters of Y.

questions.prompt: For edit distance with unit costs, dp[i][j] can be computed from dp[i-1][j], dp[i][j-1], and dp[i-1][j-1].
questions.explanation: Insert, delete, and substitute correspond to dp[i][j-1], dp[i-1][j], and dp[i-1][j-1] transitions.

questions.prompt: Held–Karp for TSP is an example of DP over:
questions.explanation: Held–Karp uses DP over subsets of visited cities and an endpoint, leading to O(n^2 2^n) time.

questions.prompt: The typical time complexity of Held–Karp TSP is O(n^2 · _____).
questions.explanation: Held–Karp runs in O(n^2 2^n) time by iterating over all subsets and endpoints.

questions.prompt: Which optimization can reduce a DP from O(n^2) space to O(n) space in many problems?
options: Keeping only the previous row/column when transitions are local
questions.explanation: If dp[i][*] depends only on dp[i-1][*] (or a constant number of prior rows), you can roll arrays and reduce space.

questions.prompt: Knuth optimization applies to certain interval DP recurrences when:
options: Quadrangle inequality / monotone optima conditions hold
questions.explanation: Knuth optimization reduces O(n^3) interval DP to O(n^2) when the argmin is monotone and the cost function satisfies required properties.

questions.prompt: Bitset convolution tricks can sometimes speed up subset DP for moderate n by using word-level parallelism.
questions.explanation: Representing sets as bitsets can accelerate transitions via bit operations and SIMD-like parallelism, although it depends on the DP structure.

questions.prompt: A common technique to speed up DP transitions is to maintain the best candidate in a monotone queue (a form of _____ optimization).
questions.explanation: Certain DP recurrences can be optimized using convex hull trick (CHT) or monotone queue techniques when transitions have linear/convex structure.

questions.prompt: For subset DP, a typical state is dp[S][v], where S is a subset and v is:
questions.explanation: Subset DP often tracks the cost of visiting exactly S and ending at v (e.g., Held–Karp). v encodes the “last” choice.

questions.prompt: Which statement about DP is generally true?
options: DP trades space for time by reusing computed subproblems
questions.explanation: DP stores intermediate results to avoid recomputation, often reducing exponential recursion to polynomial time at the cost of additional memory.
